prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We selected the H2O-18 4_14-3_21 line at 390.6~GHz in band 8 for this ALMA high resolution follow up. It has comparable transmission as the 322.5~GHz line, but is lower in energy and potential line blending by ethyl cyanide in two of the sources can be accounted for (see Figure in proposal) while the 322.5~GHz line is blended with an unknown line.
From modelling of high excitation lines of methyl cyanide and its 13C isotopologue observed with APEX we get typical source sizes of the high temperature components of the core of 1~arcsec, hence we aim at angular resolution of 0.15~arcsec to clearly resolve the cores. These CH_3CN lines will also be covered in the ALMA setup in the USB. Another indication of a typical 1 arcsec size comes from the physical models of Rolffs et al. for the sources. They reach temperatures of 200K at radii of 0.5arcsec. We computed RATRAN water data cubes using these models and observed them with the ALMA simulator, again showing about 1arcsec as the size scale. Note, that fragmentation and/or disks will likely lead to further substructure on this scale. ATCA 3mm observations of the sources with 2arcsec resolution clearly show compact emission (Wyrowski et al. 2008; Dedes et al. 2011) towards the hot cores.
Covering many lines of C2H5CN is crucial to properly assess and correct for a potential blend of C2H5CN with the H2O-18 line. In the other sideband, the large variety of CH3CN J=22-21 is key, together with the CH3OH observations in Band 9, to improve the physical models of the observed sources. These lines will provide a legacy on their own. All these lines will be an important complement to the water observations, helping to constrain the physical and chemical conditions of the cores and will provide a legacy on their own. Therefore we request for the observations the high datarate.
For the water line, we aim at a spectral resolution of 0.4km/s, enough to clearly resolve the lines with typical width in single dish observations of 4-8km/s. To cover additional lines of C2H5CN, CH3CN v=0, v8=1, CH3C-13-N needed for the modeling of the sources, we cover with 0.8km/s large fraction of the receiver bands. This will also lead to excellent continuum S/N, so that self-calibration can be used on the long baselines. In our APEX observations the water lines have fluxes of about 20-30Jy. Distributing this flux in the worst case evenly into a source of 1arcsec size and asking for signal-to-noise of 10, we need to reach a noise level of about 0.04Jy/beam.

The water line at 658~GHz, which is the vibrationally excited equivalent of the ortho-water ground state line at 556.9~GHz, will be observed in Band 9. No blending lines from other abundant species could be found at this frequency.
As an additional optically thin probe of water, we cover also at 658.5Ghz the H2O-17 5_32-4_41 line. In the other sideband C17O (6-5) as well as the bands from J=14-13 highly excited methanol in ground and torsionally excited states are observed. The methanol lines have energies from about 300 to 1000K above ground, hence complement ideally the observations of vibrationally excited water. The optically thin C17O will measure as a reference the CO column density. All these lines will be an important complement to the water observations, helping to constrain the physical and chemical conditions of the cores and will provide a legacy on their own.
From the rotational diagram analysis we show in the proposal, the line could in principle be also originate from an about 200K component of the core, but given it high excitation, it will likely be more compact, we assume here 0.5arcsec as an upper limit. We ask for beam matched observations between band 8 and 9, hence a synthezized beam of 0.15arcsec also in band 9. Two sources have already been tentatively detected in the line with APEX while in the other two sources we only get upper limits of about 15Jy. Assuming 10Jy and distributing the flux evenly into 0.5arcsec with the requirement of a S/N of 10, we need to reach 0.1Jy/beam. The spectral resolution of 0.5km/s is sufficient to resolve the lines with widths of 4-8km/s. Calibration on the long baselines can be aided by self-calibration on the strong dust continuum of the hot cores.

We selected the H2O-18 4_14-3_21 line at 390.6~GHz in band 8 for this ALMA high resolution follow up. It has comparable transmission as the 322.5~GHz line, but is lower in energy and potential line blending by ethyl cyanide in two of the sources can be accounted for (see Figure in proposal) while the 322.5~GHz line is blended with an unknown line.
From modelling of high excitation lines of methyl cyanide and its 13C isotopologue observed with APEX we get typical source sizes of the high temperature components of the core of 1~arcsec, hence we aim at angular resolution of 0.15~arcsec to clearly resolve the cores. These CH_3CN lines will also be covered in the ALMA setup in the USB. Another indication of a typical 1 arcsec size comes from the physical models of Rolffs et al. for the sources. They reach temperatures of 200K at radii of 0.5arcsec. We computed RATRAN water data cubes using these models and observed them with the ALMA simulator, again showing about 1arcsec as the size scale. Note, that fragmentation and/or disks will likely lead to further substructure on this scale. SMA mm observations of the sources with 1-2arcsec resolution clearly show compact emission (Hunter et al. 2006; Leurini et al. 2011) towards the main hot cores.
Covering many lines of C2H5CN is crucial to properly assess and correct for a potential blend of C2H5CN with the H2O-18 line. In the other sideband, the large variety of CH3CN J=22-21 is key, together with the CH3OH observations in Band 9, to improve the physical models of the observed sources. These lines will provide a legacy on their own. All these lines will be an important complement to the water observations, helping to constrain the physical and chemical conditions of the cores and will provide a legacy on their own. Therefore we request for the observations the high datarate.
For the water line, we aim at a spectral resolution of 0.4km/s, enough to clearly resolve the lines with typical width in single dish observations of 4-8km/s. To cover additional lines of C2H5CN, CH3CN v=0, v8=1, CH3C-13-N needed for the modeling of the sources, we cover with 0.8km/s large fraction of the receiver bands. This will also lead to excellent continuum S/N, so that self-calibration can be used on the long baselines. In our APEX observations the water lines have fluxes of about 20-30Jy. Distributing this flux in the worst case evenly into a source of 1arcsec size and asking for signal-to-noise of 10, we need to reach a noise level of about 0.04Jy/beam.

The water line at 658~GHz, which is the vibrationally excited equivalent of the ortho-water ground state line at 556.9~GHz, will be observed in Band 9. No blending lines from other abundant species could be found at this frequency.
As an additional optically thin probe of water, we cover also at 658.5Ghz the H2O-17 5_32-4_41 line. In the other sideband C17O (6-5) as well as the bands from J=14-13 highly excited methanol in ground and torsionally excited states are observed. The methanol lines have energies from about 300 to 1000K above ground, hence complement ideally the observations of vibrationally excited water. The optically thin C17O will measure as a reference the CO column density. All these lines will be an important complement to the water observations, helping to constrain the physical and chemical conditions of the cores and will provide a legacy on their own.
From the rotational diagram analysis we show in the proposal, the line could in principle be also originate from an about 200K component of the core, but given it high excitation, it will likely be more compact, we assume here 0.5arcsec as an upper limit. We ask for beam matched observations between band 8 and 9, hence a synthezized beam of 0.15arcsec also in band 9. Two sources have already been tentatively detected in the line with APEX while in the other two sources we only get upper limits of about 15Jy. Assuming 10Jy and distributing the flux evenly into 0.5arcsec with the requirement of a S/N of 10, we need to reach 0.1Jy/beam. The spectral resolution of 0.5km/s is sufficient to resolve the lines with widths of 4-8km/s. Calibration on the long baselines can be aided by self-calibration on the strong dust continuum of the hot cores.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Water controls the chemistry of many other molecular species. It is a unique diagnostic of warm gas and energetic processes taking place during star formation. Observations of water was one of the key science themes of the Herschel space mission. However within the 10-40 arcsec FWHM of Herschel, the water emission regions remain unresolved. Fortunately, some high-excitation lines of water and its rare 18O isotopologue can be observed from the exceptional ALMA high site. In particular, it will be possible to spatially resolve the hot inner envelope of massive proto-cluster in which water is evaporated from the ice mantles of dust grains. In these regions water might rival CO in abundance and with its many lines of high excitation, will provide a new tool to study the inner workings of massive star forming regions, in particular their water abundances, excitation and velocity structure and morphology (disk vs. envelope components), thereby crucially enhancing the value of the water observations we obtained with Herschel/HIFI with high resolution ALMA images of high excitation lines.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: SRON Groningen, SRON Netherlands Institute for Space Research
